threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

last_replies.com:
Just play K groove
But if you insist, you have to blend roll into the motion you're doing. There different methods for stuff like charge motions or mash inputs (hands,kicks, lightning etc).

But to keep it simple, for something like ryu's fireball the idea is to do down, downforward + roll, forward + mp/hp

You can roll cancel light fb but it's a little tricker
If you're gonna start somewhere try getting that down, if you do it right you'll see ryu do the roll startup briefly and then do the fireball. A better way to test it is to make an ai dummy in training mode throw fireballs at you and try to rc fireball through them as ryu

last_replies.com:
>>9447404
>Thinking about picking up a soldering kit if anyone has any recommendations!
I'm not gonna recommend you a specific brand like some shill, but I have some recommendations.
Don't buy ANY soldering iron unless you can easily find replacement tips of different types online for sale. If you can't replace the tip, the iron is trash the moment the current tip gets damaged. You will also be stuck with whatever size tip it comes with. You don't want that. Look for replacement tips for the iron BEFORE you buy. If there's a wide selection, carry on. If they are rare or unobtainium, avoid that iron. As for having a temp readout VS just an adjustment dial, it's up to you. I started and do my current solder work on an iron with just an adjustment knob and no temp reading, but you do you.
Buy a few different types of solder, not just one. There are people who hate lead-free solder, I've never had any issue with it. Some swear by solid core, some won't touch an iron without rosin-core. Try a few, see what works best for you and not some faggot on the internet. They are $2-3 per small coil, so it's not like you're going to be out a ton of money on solder. There is no "right" acid-free solder, only the right one for you. No matter which one you use, you'll want to use flux, so buy a big jar of that. Flux is flux, use whatever flux looks good to you.
Get a desoldering bulb. Desoldering guns are fancy, but have filters that require constant replacement in order to keep operational. The bulb is $10ish and just werks, at worst you might need to clean the tip with a paper-clip. Also get a desoldering braid for when you're ready to attempt SMD components. A few cans of Electrical Contact Cleaner and a soft-bristled tooth brush are also good to have for cleaning boards and removing leftover flux.

>>9446123
>They have a compatibility thing called Rosetta now

rosetta 2 is only for translating x86-64/AMD64 instructions to ARM64. 32-bit programs running on a 64-bit operating system often require a compatibility layer (which is not emulation).

on windows, this is WOW64, and is why there's two different versions of a bunch of DLL files and other shit. on macOS, the compatibility layer for 32-bit macOS software has been stripped out. like anything, im sure autists will hack it back in (check out winevdm for autists getting 16-bit programs running on 64-bit windows, which fixes old win16 installers and even games), but because the macOS crowd is much smaller and heavily comprised of normalfags i don't see this happening, at least not soon.

>This certainly fucked the few devs around that were dedicated to doing Mac ports and the the game library people had with them

it fucks pretty much every usecase i had for macs. this isn't the first time they've done this shit needlessly.

see:
rosetta 1 (powerPC to x86 shell integrated emulation) being removed after 5 years
classic environment (mac os =<9 compatibility layer *and* m68k emulator) being removed after 7 years

meanwhile, i can run 25-30 year old software without issue on windows (and those same windows programs run fine on linux through wine)

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Why were most of the 8-bit palettes in classic shooters devoid of any cyan? Was it an attempt to differentiate themselves from Wolfenstein 3D which had the weird idiosyncrasy of making all metal cyan?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447353
No, it wasn't. Usually colour #0 or #7 was used as transparent in Doom. Therefore the actual colour value is meaningless, and those colours in PLAYPAL don't even correspond to cyan.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447182
You do see those kinds of colors in nature though.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447353
This is an artifact of third party editing programs, the actual color they used for transparency when making Doom was this pale red color.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447359
My bad, it was just the color most editors used as transparency

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447257
Grayscale amounts to 5-bit luminance, which is exactly what you get in 16bpp games. The other colors should be weighed based on matrix coefficients, so blue should only have 4 shades. For even better results, the gradients should be based on the PQ curve.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: If you didn't own an N64 by the end of 1996 you're not allowed to have an opinion on it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9441768
Thirdworlderfag here. Most of my school buddies were poor too, but they could spend their money paying less than 1$ per hour to play PS1 games in a local rental store after school. I was one of the first lucky ones to afford N64 here. The console cost me as much as a half monthly average wage where I live. And that heavy price was while ditching the expensive taxes after looking for a small store to pay cheap. And they even accepted my old SNES with games as trade for a discount.

I never afforded buying games so I only rented. But even when renting every weekend from 2 different stores and being the first one to play (because nearly nobody afforded the console), there were still not enough new N64 game releases to play. Then I saw that my school buddy who had an old PS1 was getting much more new games on cheap pirated disks.

By reading gaming magazines I was aware that I wasn't getting many N64 games because they were not releasing enough while PS1 was getting much more new games with no port to N64. The same magazine had been shilling to N64 over a year prior to the console release as "Ultra 64" in Japan. By that time they were told that the thumb stick was a "mystery button" and that the company wouldn't tell anyone what that "button" was for. They also said that the company was even planning a project to add online connection to N64. The console was going to be released in February in Japan on that same year but they changed the date later.

One year after getting my N64 and still not having enough games being released and ports being delayed. I got my PS1 with 2 dual shocks for one third of N64 heavy price through smuggling to avoid taxation and also bought a huge amount of pirated PS1 game disks for much cheaper than renting from N64 small library. While owning both consoles N64 would only be good to play the Rareware and Nintendo titles. If it wasn't for those titles N64 would be useless to me.

threads.com:
In modern controllers natural resting position of index finger is on top of triggers.
So for retro consoles without triggers it makes more sense to map shoulder buttons to triggers.
For PS1/PS2/Ps3 most of the time it makes more sense to swap L1,R1 with L2,R2 given triggers are the main buttons right now unlike in the past. Button prompts do get confusing.
Also there is no travel distance with triggers as our fingers act instantaneous and given you are mapping a digital button to an analog button it would get activated as soon as you press.
There's a reason Nintendo is using triggers even digital buttons. Its comfy.

Do you prefer shoulder buttons or triggers for shoulder buttons?

The closest thing I can think of to what you're describing is the Yu-Gi-Oh! Tag Force series, where you play as a millennia-old robot stuck in a time loop.
I really enjoy the gameplay of the series because you start out incredibly, ridiculously weak, but with skill and planning you can become disgustingly powerful to the point where nobody can touch you. There's a great deal of strategy involved, as you gain power not only by getting better spells and learning how to use them well, but also by arranging them in your spellbook in a better configuration.
The first game in the series is the weakest, especially because it has a hidden mechanic where your party members rapidly lose affection if you don't talk to them every day, but it's also best to play through the games in order to fully appreciate the story.

threads.com:
Right, I started this today and I have some thoughts

First and foremost being the original 2000 demo lighting and finisher mogs the finishied first level which ends like a limp dick
That aside, as I thought of the demo, this game is lightyears ahead of its time. Third person shooter on the face but it's actually a puzzle game that puts everyone's skillset to use through context hover, and lets you rapidly switch between the party by looking at them/right click menu or hotkey, quality example and what sold me on it was hacking a terminal with the jap, running a robot into a gas chamber attached to that terminal and then the repairman afrter the robot disabled the gas, all this with a right click then left click on relevant portrait, then switching back to the leader and turning too sharply and watching him climb a fence and plummet to his death (didn't game over), he just respawned at the regen checkpoint in embarrassment

Just so far it has remote control cars, levels that stretch out to a degree that the devs basically flaunt areas before they unleash the puzzles on you to get there, TPS combat and a plot straight our of Dredd
And I really need to mention the plot, for one, it starts on a dick joke (real meat? I'll show you real meat). And it's like if Dredd went wrong and they sent in a cleanup crew to see where their agents went, parallels with The Raid also work but the closest I've found to that experience in-game is ragdolling cunts with robot missiles

It's basically a perfect game and 75% off on GOG, do rec (just rename or delete the logos intro in the folder and it works beautifully on modern OS ((The chunky robot has a hard time registering context memes like doorknobs, personally I put that down to it being such a big bastard and trying smaller humans is an easier time, not sure if that was intended)

Yes, I too saw that LTT video.

How badly if at all would converting retro systems to use USB-C instead of their now decades old PSUs effect any sort of interference or image/audio quality? Or could it fry any other aftermarket modifications like ODEs or HDMI mods?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446301
>or the quality of the image or sound
Yes, absolutely. The mod itself shouldn't make noise, but USB power supplies are unbelievably noisy. Turn on an AM radio next to one sometime, it's just a blast of interference.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446316
Can you get a good quality one that would output cleaner power?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446334
Yeah, Apple's chargers are expensive but they're actually reliable and better than most. The real problem is that no one shields anything anymore because the FCC doesn't care, so even good USB stuff is pretty noisy. It's also worth noting that if you mistakenly plug a USB-C PD charger into a console you've modded for USB-C, you could blow it up with 20V or something. Not everything is the same old 5V we've grown accustomed to from USB power anymore. That's why I like the dumb things I posted above, no mods needed (for me anyway, I mostly stick to 8-bit machines), they're easy to replace and if they die they can't spit out more than the 5V they're being fed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446350
>It's also worth noting that if you mistakenly plug a USB-C PD charger into a console you've modded for USB-C, you could blow it up with 20V or something.

Isn't that the whole reason that USB-PD requires circuity to regulate voltage otherwise it will only deliver the default 5V of USB power? That's why the USB-C console mods either make you use a cable that has the PD circuitry to deliver the right voltage or have that circuitry in the replacement power supply/adapter itself.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

Sonic was the mascot of the most popular arcade operator in the entire country and they plastered his face all over. Everyone knew who Sonic was, it's just that the Mega Drive wasn't popular. The Mega Drive and the Game Gear didn't sell very well, but the little bit of sales that they did get is thanks to Sonic. While the vast majority of games for those platforms remain incredibly expensive in Japan, Sonic is one of the few titles that remains cheap because essentially everyone who owned the console was a fan of Sonic.

Sonic Jam and Sonic R both sold well in Japan, as did the Sknic Adventure games. And then after Sega went third party the series continued to sell well on other platforms. Sure he's not the most successful brand in the nation, but it's not as if he was a failure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9444381

An arcade collector said something to me that has stuck in mind ever since. He said:

"Remember when you are buying an arcade cabinet that you are buying an *antique*."

It really hit me when he said antique. The cabinets I grew up with in the 80s and 90s are now 30+ years old. They were never designed to last this long. Controllers break. Motherboards fail. Monitors burn out. Even if you bought an arcade cabinet fresh from the factory in the 1990s, left it in climate controlled storage, and never used it.....the arcade cabinet would still have problems if you tried to use it today.

But they survive because we keep them alive. It is what we do as arcade collectors.

At 30 years old, owning an original arcade cabinet requires maintainance and repairs. It is a way of life.

threads.sub: Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing appreciation thread
threads.com:
As we all know, the Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing series spans across 5 decades, starting in 1986 on MS-DOS and stretching throughout multiple generations well into the 21st century.
This thread is made in appreciation to the series as it moved throughout the ever-changing landscape of the digital world and adapted to it.
It was unique in its day for its emphasis on improving one skill: typing. Mavis Beacon leads you to become a proficient typist with an exceptional WPM count.
There were many other typing games throughout these generations
>Mario Teaches Typing
>Typing of the Dead
Are among the most well-known, but there is only one Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing.

While I don't personally use them, I can let all the filter effects slide except the bowing.
If your picture bowed or was otherwise warped, your set was miscalibrated. I don't think I ever even saw anyone's set like that in person and I lived through that era.
If it didn't come correct from the factory, it took all of 2 seconds to fiddle with the nobs or and OSD if you're fancy.
It reminds me of how kids today think VHS tapes all looked like they had decades of ware on them, when they were new.
You can say that games were designed for pixel bleeding, etc. but I'm pretty sure nobody ever intended for their games to be played on a bowed screen on purpose.
